Most probably it is a case of Milia. A milium is a small cyst containing keratin (the skin protein). Milia do not need to be treated unless they are a cause for concern for the patient. They often clear up by themselves within a few months. Where possible, further trauma should be minimized to reduce the development of new lesions. The lesion may be de-roofed using a sterile needle or blade and the contents squeezed or pricked out.
They may be destroyed using diathermy and curettage, or cryotherapy.

Most probably this is a case of blind pimple. Blind pimples are pimples (zits) that form under your skin. They may stay under your skin’s surface, causing pain and inflammation. Or they may erupt through the surface in the form of a whitehead, blackhead, or red bump. Treatment includes warm compresses and acne-fighting creams containing salicylic acid. Use topical creams and gels like antibiotic cream and retinoid cream. Keep your skin clean to reduce the chance of getting a blind pimple.

Most probably it is a case of inflamed pimple, may be due to folliculitis or acne. As it's beginning to disappear you can just wait and follow up if further changes occur. You can also try topical steroid cream for a few days if still inflamed.

Most probably it is a case of solar lentigo, a harmless condition that happens on prolonged sun exposure. Examination using dermatoscopy can clarify the diagnosis. Use topical moisturizer containing aloe vera, and use creams containing licorice extract and vitamin C. There are many topical creams available over the counter that you can apply at home to remove sunspots. Look for creams containing glycolic acid, hydroxy acid, or kojic acid. Taking a vitamin E supplement offers protection against sun damage and can improve your skin’s health, especially when taken together with vitamin C. Use high SPF sunscreen to avoid sun damage.

Most propably it is a case of a cyst in the groin area. Cysts are non-cancerous lumps that can cause discomfort or pain, especially when they grow in size. It is important not to squeeze or pop a cyst as this can cause infection. Similarly, if a cyst bursts under your skin, it can cause the surrounding tissue to become infected. There are hundreds of different types of cysts that form for many different reasons, such as infections or blockages in ducts. You should consult your dermatologist for surgical excision.

This is a case of contact eczema most probably due to contact with an irritant. It’s a common condition that isn’t contagious. Symptoms of eczema can flare up if you contact an irritant or an allergen. Use gentle or sensitive skin moisturizers throughout the day when you have dry skin. Apply moisturizer when your skin is damp after a bath or shower. Apply topical medications to your skin like topical hydrocortisone cream. Take oral medications like anti inflammatory medicines, antihistamines, or corticosteroids to reduce itchiness and swelling. Choose skin care moisturizers that are hypoallergenic, fragrance- and dye-free, gentle or for sensitive skin, contain petroleum jelly or mineral oil, don’t include preservatives or stabilizers, and have lipids and ceramides to improve your skin’s barrier. Avoid irritants and allergens.

It is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appears when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment, and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

Most probably it is a case of deep coarse wrinkle that forms due to chronic sun exposure, facial muscle contraction, smoking, and aging. Retinoids that include retinol, retinal aldehyde (Retin-A), retinyl esters, adapalene, tazarotene, and tretinoin are chemicals that come from vitamin A that help reduce lines and wrinkles in your skin and improve your skin’s texture, pigment and hydration levels. You can find retinol in many over-the-counter skin care products. Retinol can penetrate deep into your skin’s layers to activate collagen and elastin, which give your skin structure and support to prevent wrinkles. Also, you can try nonsurgical procedures at the dermatology clinic like microneedling, chemical peeling, laser resurfacing, Botox injection, and soft tissue fillers injection.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

Cold, dry weather, sun damage, and frequently licking your lips are just some of the reasons your lips might feel dry and chapped. Use non-irritating lip balm, lipstick, and other products that you apply to your lips. If your lips burn, sting, or feel uncomfortable when you apply a product to your lips, it means you’re irritating your lips, so you want to stop using that product. Ingredients that can help heal chapped lips are castor seed oil, ceramides, dimethicone, hemp seed oil, mineral oil, petrolatum, shea butter, sun-protective ingredients, such as titanium oxide or zinc oxide, and white petroleum jelly. It also helps to use products that are fragrance free and hypoallergenic. Apply a non-irritating lip balm (or lip moisturizer) several times a day and before bed. Slather on a non-irritating lip balm with SPF 30 or higher before going outdoors. Apply the lip balm every 2 hours. Drink plenty of water. Chapped lips are dry lips, so you want to stay hydrated. Stop licking, biting, and picking at your lips.

Basically getting rid of the itch begins with finding out why your scalp itches, If your scalp is dry and itchy and you see flakes on your hair or clothing, you may have dandruff. Leaving some shampoo on your scalp can also irritate it.  An itchy scalp is the most common symptom of head lice, too. If you suspect that head lice are causing the itch, ask someone to closely examine your scalp and hair for signs of these tiny bugs. Seborrheic dermatitis is also a possible cause for this itching if you have oily and greasy flakes. Severe itching usually results in scalp injury and propably secondary infection (folliculitis) which is the case here. Treatment of the cause of itchy scalp is the mainstay for preventing folliculitis. Anti-dandruff shampoos are essential for people with straight or wavy hair who usually shampoo every day while people with curly or tightly coiled hair are likely to shampoo once a week. Shampoo containing 2% zinc pyrithione, 1% ketoconazole or 1% selenium sulfide is recommended and sometimes topoical hydrocortisone creams or lotions are needed. To get seborrheic dermatitis under control, it’s important to leave the shampoo on your scalp for 5-10 minutes, this gives the medication time to work. You also want to thoroughly rinse off the shampoo. Skin with seborrheic dermatitis is easily irritated. If you have shampoo residue on your skin or scalp, it could cause a flare-up. You need to get rid of the lice if it is the cause of itching. For folliculitis, you can also try topical antibiotic cream (e.g. fusidic acid gel), clindamycin solution, erythromycin solution, mild topical steroid lotions or creams, oral antihistamines, oral antibiotics, particularly long-term tetracycline. Oral isotretinoin, a long-term low-dose treatment may be required. If that doesn't help, or your condition worsens, consult a dermatologist.

Most probably, it is a case of keratoacanthoma, a common rapidly growing locally destructive skin tumour. Keratoacanthoma is most common in fair-skinned older males with a history of chronic sun exposure. It is more common in immunosuppressed individuals. Referral to a dermatologist is a must for skin biopsy. Keratoacanthoma is regarded as benign and thus has an excellent prognosis following surgical excision. Cryosurgery, curettage and electrodessication, topical or intralesional chemotherapy (5-fluorouracil, imiquimod, bleomycin, methotrexate) are also therapeutic options.

It is a case of Pityriasis versicolor, a common yeast infection of the skin, in which flaky discoloured patches appear on the chest and back. Pityriasis versicolor is more common in hot, humid climates than in cool, dry climates. It often affects people who perspire heavily. It may clear in the winter months and recur each summer. Although it is not considered infectious in the conventional sense, pityriasis versicolor sometimes affects more than one member of a family.Mild pityriasis versicolor is treated with topical antifungal agents. Selenium sulfide shampoo, Topical azole cream/shampoo (econazole, ketoconazole), Terbinafine gel. The medicine should be applied widely to the skin from the jawline down and left on the skin for 5-15 minutes before rinsing off in the shower. This should be done daily for one week then weekly for one month. Oral antifungal agents, itraconazole and fluconazole, are used to treat pityriasis versicolor when extensive or if topical agents have failed. Vigorous exercise an hour after taking the medication may help sweat it onto the skin surface, where it can effectively eradicate the yeast. Bathing should be avoided for a few hours. A few days' treatment will clear many cases of pityriasis long term, or at least for several months. Reapplication of a topical treatment such as selenium sulfide shampoo every month once the rash has cleared will usually prevent recurrence.

It is a case of rosacea. Rosacea is a chronic inflammatory skin condition predominantly affecting the central face and most often starts between the age of 30–60 years. Rosacea is common and is characterised by persistent facial redness. It typically has a relapsing and remitting course, with symptoms controlled by lifestyle measures, general skin care, medications, and procedural interventions. Rosacea has been associated with depression, hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, anxiety disorder, dyslipidemia, diabetes mellitus, migraine, rheumatoid arthritis, Helicobacter pylori infection, ulcerative colitis, and dementia. Identify the trigger (Common triggers include spicy food, hot/cold temperatures (hot baths), exercise, sun exposure, cosmetic products, medications (those that cause vasodilation), alcohol, fruits and vegetables, dairy, marinated meat products) and avoid it. Moisturise frequently. Use gentle over-the-counter cleansers. Use mild, synthetic detergent-based cleansers rather than traditional soaps due to risk of irritation. Use physical sunscreens ( zinc oxide/titanium oxide) with SPF ≥ 30, provides broad-spectrum UV radiation and visible light protection and may be better tolerated than chemical sunscreens. Avoid exfoliants. Avoid alcohol-based topical products. Avoid use of topical steroids as they may aggravate the condition. Cosmetics with a green tint are useful to minimise the appearance of redness. Use topical brimonidine, topical oxymetazoline, intense pulsed light therapy, vascular laser, topical azelaic acid (for mild/moderate only), topical ivermectin, topical metronidazole (for mild/moderate only), topical erythromycin, oral tetracyclines (oxytetracycline, lymecycline, doxycycline), oral macrolides (erythromycin, azithromycin), oral metronidazole, oral isotretinoin often at low dose (for refractory disease only). Although rosacea is not a life-threatening condition, it is a chronic disease that requires long-term management of relapsing and remitting symptoms.

The best way to lighten a tan is to avoid getting it in the first place. Protect your skin and prevent unwanted tanning with proper sun protection. Always wear a hat, sun protective clothing, and sunscreen when outside. Sunscreen should be reapplied every two hours. You can try topical treatments containing ingredients that can lighten the skin such as azelaic acid, cysteamine cream, vitamin C, hydroquinone, corticosteroids, kojic acid, licorice, retinoids such as tretinoin, arbutin, glycolic acid peels, mequinol, niacinamide. Creams containing steroids and hydroquinone can take 3–6 months to affect the skin color. Always purchase products from a reputable source and follow the instructions on the pack. Cosmetic procedures can be also tried like laser therapy, intense pulsed light and chemical peels. Avoid sun exposure

Dry thickened skin (callus) around the rim of the heel is the very first step towards cracking. Increased pressure on the fat pad under the heel causes it to expand sideways, leading to splitting or cracking of the callus. Some factors that contribute to cracking or splitting include excessive weight or obesity, Prolonged standing, especially on hard floors, and Open-back shoes and sandals, as they provide no support to hold the fat pad under the foot. You can try rubbing the heels with a moisturising cream on a regular basis to keep the skin supple and hydrated. Special heel balms are available that contain descaling (keratolytic) or water-retaining (humectant) agents, such as:
Urea, Salicylic acid, Alpha-hydroxy acids, Saccharide isomerate. Feet should be inspected daily and on the first sign of any cracking, a moisturising routine 2–3 times a day may be all that is needed to heal the heel. A pumice stone can be rubbed gently against the callus to take away some of the thick hard skin before applying moisturiser.

It is a case of leukoderma (loss of skin color). White spots can appear when skin proteins or dead cells become trapped under the skin’s surface. They can also result from depigmentation, or color loss, due to vitiligo, contact with chemicals, scarring, infections, burn or drugs. White skin spots are not usually a reason for concern and do not cause major symptoms. It is important, however, to have white spots checked by a dermatologist, to understand their cause and the best way to treat them. Sun protection, cosmetic camouflage, treatment of an associated or underlying cause, and Surgery (melanocyte grafting).

Most propably it is a case of hormonal acne. Acne is largely a hormonal condition that’s driven by androgen hormones (testosterone). This typically becomes active during teenage and young adult years. Mild acne can be treated with over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as gels, soaps, pads, creams, and lotions, that are applied to the skin. Creams and lotions are best for sensitive skin. Alcohol-based gels dry the skin and are better for oily skin. It is advisable to start with the lowest strengths, as some preparations can cause skin irritation, redness, or burning on first use. Topical acne medications include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.

Dry thickened skin (callus) is the very first step towards cracking. You can try rubbing with a moisturizing cream on a regular basis to keep the skin supple and hydrated. Special balms are available that contain descaling (keratolytic) or water-retaining (humectant) agents, such as Urea, Salicylic acid, Alpha-hydroxy acids, Saccharide isomerate. Feet should be inspected daily, and on the first sign of any cracking, a moisturising routine of 2–3 times a day should be started. A pumice stone can be rubbed gently against the callus to take away some of the thick hard skin before applying moisturiser. Try to avoid the cause if possible.

It is a fungal infection which is very contagious so it's important to use the right antifungal medicine as long as you can (around 2 weeks) to ensure that the ringworm does not reappear a few weeks after you stop treating it. After touching the area with ringworm, wash your hands before touching another area of your body. Ring worm thrives in warm, moist areas, so you want keep the area clean and dry. Avoid wearing clothes, socks, and shoes that make you sweat. Shower after working out and avoid sharing towels and other personal items. To avoid reinfecting yourself with infected items, you should wash clothes, towels, and bedding that you use while you have ringworm. Be sure to wash everything in hot, soapy water. If you suspect your pet has ringworm, take the animal to your vet as some types of ring worms grow on pets. Topical antifungal cream (azoles group like Miconazole or clotrimazole) twice daily for 2-4 weeks is recommended and systemic antifungal may be prescibed by your dermatologist if resistant to treatment.

It is a case of folliculitis. It happens when hair follicles become inflamed. It's often caused by an infection with bacteria. Certain factors increase the risk of getting it, including:
soaking in a hot tub, whirlpool or public pool that's not maintained well, damage to hair follicles through shaving, waxing, wearing tight clothes or excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis). To prevent this, wash your skin regularly and use a clean washcloth and towel each time and don't share your towels or washcloths, avoid friction or pressure on your skin. Use only clean hot tubs and heated pools. You can apply topical antibiotic cream twice daily for 1 week and use antiseptic wash (4% chlorhexidine).

It is a case of acne affecting the nose. The nose is particularly vulnerable because the pores in this location tend to be larger than elsewhere. Too much sebum can trap debris, such as dead skin or bacteria, in the pores.The larger size makes it easier for debris to become trapped, leading to acne breakouts. Over-the-counter treatments like Benzoyl peroxide kills bacteria and helps remove oil and dead skin cells in the pores. It can also lessen the swelling associated with pimples. Salicylic acid is helpful for unclogging the skin's pores and may prevent whiteheads from forming in the first place. Alpha hydroxy acid exfoliants (AHAs), such as glycolic acid, can unclog pores while also reducing the appearance of age spots. Retinoids may also help by opening clogged pores.

It is a case of pityriasis rosea, a self limited viral skin disorder. This could be the fragrance in your deodorant, a new laundry detergent, or the fabric of a shirt. A deodorant rash can result if you’re allergic to any of the ingredients in your deodorant, or if any of these ingredients irritate your skin. OTC anti-itch creams, such as hydrocortisone cream, may reduce inflammation. Antihistamines can help manage itching. Eliminate or swap any irritants, such as deodorants, scented soaps, or washing detergent.While the rash will go away on its own without treatment, self-care can help you feel more comfortable while you have the rash. Try to follow these tips:
Avoid shaving until the rash heals, if you have ingrown hairs.
Wear loose, cotton clothing that leaves space for air to flow under the arms.
Stay in a cool environment, as far as possible.
Take a warm (but not hot) bath with colloidal oatmeal.
Apply unscented moisturizers to soothe dry skin or eczema.
Use calamine lotion or cool compresses to soothe discomfort.
Use antichafing powders to prevent friction and absorb humidity.
Avoid scratching, which may make symptoms worse.

It is a case of ingrown hairs. You can get ingrown hairs when short, curly hairs curve back into your skin instead of growing out. For many people, this happens when they shave, which is why ingrown hairs are frequently called “razor bumps.” Encourage use of disposable razors or cleaning electric shavers with alcohol based antiseptic solution regularly to prevent infection of the grooming tool. Shave at the end of your shower or immediately afterward. This softens the hairs, so they’re less likely to curl back into your skin. Before shaving, apply a pre-shave gel and apply a fragrance-free shaving cream. Shave in the direction that your hairs grow and rinse with luke water. Gently pat your skin dry with a clean towel; leave your skin a little damp, this helps your skin retain moisture and apply a moisturizer formulated for your skin type. Use topical antibiotics such as clindamycin, mupirocin, and fusidic acid, oral antibiotics such as flucloxacillin or doxycycline,  chlorhexidine/neomycin cream for eradication of nasal carriage and topical hydrocortisone cream can be also tried.

Raised bumps on the skin can have many different causes, ranging from acne to skin cancer according to onset, duration and recent changes. Most propably it is a case of irritated mole. You may need to be checked by your health care provider for more accurate diagnosis and skin biopsy if needed.

It is a case of Cherry angioma, a benign vascular skin lesion. An angioma is due to proliferating endothelial cells; these are the cells that line the inside of a blood vessel. It is usually diagnosed clinically and investigation is not necessary for the majority of lesions. Cherry angiomas are harmless, so do not have to be treated but just follow up. If desired for cosmetic reason, Cryotherapy, Electrosurgery or Vascular laser can be used

It is a case of fungal infection associated with nail thickening. Predisposing patient factors include: chronic paronychia, hyperhidrosis (eg, with occlusive footwear), nail trauma, and using communal bathing or changing facilities. Clippings should be taken from the crumbling free edge of the affected nail. A KOH mount is a useful screening test, but a culture is considered the mainstay of diagnosis because it not only has high sensitivity, but also allows identification of the etiologic agent, so that treatment may be appropriately tailored. Treatment aims to eliminate the offending organism and restore the nail to health and a normal appearance. Fingernail infections are usually cured more quickly and effectively than toenail infections. Mild infections affecting less than 50% of one or two nails may respond to topical antifungal medication, but cure usually requires an oral antifungal medication for several months. Topical antifungal treatment options include Ciclopirox 8% lacquer. With total nail involvement, medical nail avulsion using urea paste may enhance systemic antifungal efficacy. Oral antifungal treatment options include Terbinafine, Fluconazole. Strategies to prevent recurrence include:

Keeping feet cool and dry; avoid using occlusive footwear and excessive sweating
Using thongs/flip-flops in public gyms and swimming pools
Discarding or treating infected footwear and socks
Avoiding nail trauma by trimming nails short
Avoiding unhygienic cosmetic nail practices
Using prophylactic antifungals in feet and webs
Patient counseling for optimal onychomycosis therapy to improve adherence
Addressing poorly controlled diabetes.

Most propably it is a purpuric spot. They’re caused by a blood vessel break due to injury or trauma. There are some bleeding disorders and medical conditions that may make you more prone to bruising, including taking medications to thin blood or stop clotting, such as aspirin or blood thinners and regularly taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain relief, including ibuprofen (Advil®) or naproxen (Aleve®). Most bruises fade away and don’t need treatment. More severe bruises might need treatment.

Most propably it is a case of localized eczema due to dry skin. You can start using oil-free noncomedogenic moisturizer like hyaluronic acid. If still persistent, you need to consult your dermatologist for dermoscopic examination and skin biopsy to rule out skin cancer.

It is a case of actinic keratosis (solar keratosis), a precancerous scaly spot found on sun-damaged skin, also known as solar keratosis. It may be considered an early form of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (a keratinocyte cancer). They are more likely to appear if the immune function is poor, due to ageing, recent sun exposure, predisposing disease, or certain drugs. The main concern is that actinic keratoses indicate an increased risk of developing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.  Dermoscopy is useful in diagnosis and skin biopsy is necessary for example to exclude SCC. Actinic keratoses are usually removed because they are unsightly or uncomfortable, or because of the risk that skin cancer may develop in them. Creams like 5-Flurouracil and Imiquimod are used to treat areas of sun damage and flat actinic keratoses, sometimes after physical treatments have been carried out. Pretreatment with keratolytics (such as urea cream, salicylic acid ointment or topical retinoid), and thorough skin cleansing improves response rates.Referral to a dermatologist is needed for excision, shave, curettage, cryotherapy or electrocautery.

Most propably it is a case of seborrheic keratosis. Seborrheic keratosis is a common benign (noncancerous) skin growth. Seborrheic keratoses are not pre-cancerous, but they can resemble other skin growths that are. Your healthcare provider can help diagnose your seborrheic keratosis and remove it for you if you’d like. If in doubt, your healthcare provider may look at the growth under a dermascope, a small, handheld lighted microscope. If your healthcare provider suspects any cancer, they will want to take a sample or remove the whole growth to examine in a lab. You should always have new skin growths clinically diagnosed to make sure they aren’t cancerous. Different kinds of skin growths can be hard to tell apart from each other. Some over-the-counter topical treatments have shown promise for reducing seborrheic keratoses like tazarotene cream 0.1% and
Alpha Hydroxy Acid (AHA) products, including glycolic acid and salicylic acid peels. Cryotherapy, electrotherapy, shave excision, and laser treatment are also treatment options

Most propably these are scartch marks due to itchy skin. Itchy skin may be due to dry skin, atopic dermatitis, or contact dermatitis. Try using over the counter fragrance free moisturizers containing hyaluronic acid, bees wax, ceramides or shea butter to improve your skin barrier defect and relieve itching. You can also try to use soap free cleansers to avoid more irritation. Topical hydrocortisone may be also used.

It is a case of an intradermal nevus (also called an intradermal melanocytic nevus) is simply a classic mole or birthmark. It typically appears as an elevated, dome-shaped bump on the surface of the skin. In most cases, intradermal nevi appear after adolescence and are benign (noncancerous) skin growths. An intradermal nevus is the result of one of three causes:
sun damage, especially for those with fairer skin, immunosuppressive treatments such as those used in cancer, which can cause more moles to develop, and genetic factors, such as your parents having a lot of moles, which makes it more likely that you will have them as too. Unless your mole has recently changed in size, shape or color, no treatment is necessary for an intradermal nevus. However, it is possible to remove the mole if that’s what you’d like. Electrocautery, shave excision and laser treatment are therapeutic options. Referral to a dermatologist is preferred to exclude amelanotic melanoma.

It is a case of Pityriasis versicolor, a common yeast infection of the skin, in which flaky discolored patches appear on the chest and back. Pityriasis versicolor is more common in hot, humid climates than in cool, dry climates. It often affects people who perspire heavily. It may clear in the winter months and recur each summer. Although it is not considered infectious in the conventional sense, pityriasis versicolor sometimes affects more than one member of a family. Mild pityriasis versicolor is treated with topical antifungal agents. Selenium sulfide shampoo, Topical azole cream/shampoo (econazole, ketoconazole), Terbinafine gel. The medicine should be applied widely to the skin from the jawline down and left on the skin for 5-15 minutes before rinsing off in the shower. This should be done daily for one week then weekly for one month. Oral antifungal agents, itraconazole and fluconazole, are used to treat pityriasis versicolor when extensive or if topical agents have failed. Vigorous exercise an hour after taking the medication may help sweat it onto the skin surface, where it can effectively eradicate the yeast. Bathing should be avoided for a few hours. A few days' treatment will clear many cases of pityriasis long term, or at least for several months. Reapplication of a topical treatment such as selenium sulfide shampoo every month once the rash has cleared will usually prevent recurrence.

It is a case of common wart. This non-cancerous growth appears when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

It is a case of Cherry angioma, a benign vascular skin lesion. An angioma is due to proliferating endothelial cells; these are the cells that line the inside of a blood vessel. It is usually diagnosed clinically and investigation is not necessary for the majority of lesions. Cherry angiomas are harmless, so do not have to be treated. If desired for cosmetic reasons, Cryotherapy, Electrosurgery, or Vascular laser can be used.

It is a case of Nodular melanoma where melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin presenting as a rapidly enlarging lump. It can arise de novo in normal-appearing skin or within an existing melanoma of another type. These cells may occasionally arise from an existing melanocytic naevus (about 3%) but commonly occur within another type of melanoma or in previously normal-appearing skin. What triggers the melanocytes to become malignant is unknown, but it is likely to be a series of changes to the DNA. It is essential to diagnose nodular melanoma accurately. Clinical diagnosis is aided by dermoscopy and skin biopsy (usually excision biopsy) at your dermatologist. Those with melanoma that is more than 1 mm thick may be advised to have a lymph node biopsy, imaging studies, and blood tests. The initial treatment of primary melanoma is to cut it out; the lesion should be completely excised with a 2-3 cm margin of normal tissue.

Most probably it is a case of Acneiform eruption that may affect the face and neck. Acneiform eruptions on the trunk are described as folliculitis, which may be due to infection, obstruction, or unknown irritant factors. Time course, distribution, and appearance may be helpful in making a more accurate diagnosis. The acneiform eruptions may be caused by medications, hormonal and metabolic abnormalities, drug reactions, and genetic disorders. The treatment of acneiform eruptions depends on the cause. In most cases, if the cause is an organism or a drug, then the exposure should be discontinued. Most patients recover within a few weeks. For any residual lesions, treatments that have been used to treat acneiform eruptions include laser ablation, excision, topical or oral antibiotics, drug withdrawal, or the use of topical or oral retinoids.

It is a case of urticaria, a self-limiting immunological reaction to drugs, food, bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors. Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Avoid triggers like certain types of food (eggs, peanuts) and some medications. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine or menthol lotions and creams, and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

It is a case of ingrown hairs. You can get ingrown hairs when short, curly hairs curve back into your skin instead of growing out. For many people, this happens when they shave, which is why ingrown hairs are frequently called “razor bumps.” Encourage use of disposable razors or cleaning electric shavers with alcohol based antiseptic solution regularly to prevent infection of the grooming tool. Shave at the end of your shower or immediately afterward. This softens the hairs, so they’re less likely to curl back into your skin. Before shaving, apply a pre-shave gel and apply a fragrance-free shaving cream. Shave in the direction that your hair grows and rinse with lukewarm water. Gently pat your skin dry with a clean towel; leave your skin a little damp, this helps your skin retain moisture and apply a moisturizer formulated for your skin type. Use topical antibiotics such as clindamycin, mupirocin, and fusidic acid, oral antibiotics such as flucloxacillin or doxycycline, chlorhexidine/neomycin cream for eradication of nasal carriage and topical hydrocortisone cream can be also tried.

This is a case of eczema, a skin condition that causes dry and itchy patches of skin. It’s a common condition that isn’t contagious. Symptoms of eczema can flare up if you contact an irritant or an allergen. It is triggered in dry weather, frequent hand washing, soaps, and detergents use. The connection between eczema and food allergies is unclear. Examples of common allergies include peanuts, dairy, and eggs. Use gentle or sensitive skin moisturizers throughout the day when you have dry skin. Apply moisturizer when your skin is damp after a bath or shower. Apply topical medications to your skin like topical steroids. Take oral medications like anti-inflammatory medicines, antihistamines, or corticosteroids to reduce itchiness and swelling. Choose skin care moisturizers that are hypoallergenic, fragrance and dye free, gentle or for sensitive skin, contain petroleum jelly or mineral oil, don’t include preservatives or stabilizers, and have lipids and ceramides to improve your skin’s barrier. Avoid irritants and allergens.

It is a case of eczema called dyshidrotic eczema. It is aggravated by atopic dermatitis, excessive sweating, sun exposure, and smoking. Avoid aggravating factors where possible. Potassium permanganate soaks may be useful in the acute phase. Apply topical treatments like topical steroids (usually potent or ultrapotent), pimecrolimus and tacrolimus, and regular use of emollients and moisturizers.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis), contact, allergy or atopic eczema. Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin. For example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing,  use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, antipruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If persistent, it is recommended to consult your dermatologist. It is also worth mentioning the duration of the lesion may rise Becker's nevus, a non-cancerous large brown birthmark occurring mostly in males, as a possible diagnosis.

The most possible diagnosis is a birthmark especially that it lacks any symptom of itching or dicomfort. Other possible causes of rash include eczema (mostly in atopic dermatitis), contact dermatitis (if he is allergic or sensitive to a new soap, lotion, or laundry detergent), chafing (by the frequent friction of skin rubbing against the skin from walking, running, or exercising), or heat rash (in hot weather or following a strenuous workout). Referral to a dermatologist for more accurate diagnosis is needed. No need for treatment in case it is a birthmark, while other treatment options include bathing in warm (not hot) water, using a regular moisturizer containing aloe vera, petroleum jelly or shea butter, avoiding harsh scents or products, using topical medications like topical corticosteroid cream, and cool compresses

It is a case of benign growth, lipoma or adnexal tumor that arises either from sweat glands or ducts, hair follicles or sebaceous glands. Referral to surgery or a dermatologist for local complete surgical excision and pathological examination is preferred.

This is the classic "breakfast, lunch, and dinner" pattern of dog and cat fleas, as well as bedbugs feeding by biting their victims. The parasites "map" the skin area in search of the best places to bite, and their removal when victim scratches, and then reattach to the skin. Treatment includes antihistamines to control the itching and reduction of the allergic response and topical corticosteroid cream for regression of the lesions. Do not scratch the lesions in order to avoid secondary bacterial infections caused by contamination of the injured skin with the animal's feces and bacteria. You should also avoid warm baths in order not to amplify the reactional process and aggravate the pruritis. Preventive measures consist of eliminating the parasites from the environment (indoors and yards) and from the preferentially infested domestic animals.

Most probably this is a case of angiofibroma, benign vascular neoplasm composed of dermal fibrous tissue and blood vessels. Although angiofibromas are benign, they are persistent. Angiofibromas can be removed for cosmetic or pain-related reasons. Options for treatment of angiofibromas include excision,  dermabrasion, using lasers, electrical, and radiofrequency devices, and cryotherapy. Referral to a dermatologist for dermoscopic examination is recommended to exclude basal cell carcinoma.

Most propably these are bruises or ecchymosis. These form when blood pools under your skin. They’re caused by a blood vessel break. There are some bleeding disorders and medical conditions that may make you more prone to bruising, including taking medications to thin blood or stop clotting, such as aspirin or blood thinners and regularly taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain relief, including ibuprofen (Advil®) or naproxen (Aleve®). Most bruises fade away and don’t need treatment. More severe bruises might need treatment.

It is a case of Habit-tic deformity (HTD), a type of acquired psychodermatosis affecting the nail unit. It is caused by nail picking, primarily directed at the proximal nail fold. This can be a type of obsessive-compulsive behavior. Treatment for HTD centers around prevention of further damage to the affected nail plate/s to allow healing, and breaking the cycle of ongoing habitual nail trauma. You can use physical barriers to reduce trauma to the nail bed such as bandages, tape, or glue. Stress management techniques include meditation, music therapy, and regular exercise. Replacement behaviours e.g. making a fist, squeezing a stress ball, or sitting on hands. Dermatological support groups and psychotherapy would also help. Habit-tic nail deformity generally responds well to habit reversal, although sometimes permanent nail dystrophy can result from chronic nail manipulation.

You need to see a dermatologist for dermoscopic examination of this lesion and skin biopsy if needed. The dermoscopic examination is a useful adjunct for pigmented lesions to help identify worrisome pigment patterns. Regular self-examinations of your skin will help you detect a difference in a mole over time. An easy way to remember how to check your skin is to use the ABCDE technique to identify changes.
Asymmetry - Each half of the mole is a different shape
Border - Look for spreading or irregular edges
Colour - A recent change or blotchy spots with many colors
Diameter - Spots are getting bigger 
Evolving - Changing or growing in size, shape or thickness.

Erythema ab igne (EAI) is a skin reaction caused by chronic exposure to infrared radiation in the form of heat. The source of chronic heat exposure must be avoided. If the area is only mildly affected with slight redness, the condition will resolve by itself over several months. Treatment with topical tretinoin or laser may improve the appearance.

Of course you should seek medical advice as the wound is not healing properly. Referral to surgery is recommended to avoid improper healing.

Cherry angiomas are common and typically nothing to worry about. But if they bleed or change appearance, consider consulting with a doctor. Any growth that changes in appearance, whether in shape, size, or color, or bleeds, can potentially be an indicator of skin cancer. Skin biopsy might be recommended.

It’s a case of ring worm infection, a very contagious infection so it's important to use the right antifungal medicine as long as you can (around 2 weeks) to ensure that the ringworm does not reappear a few weeks after you stop treating it. After touching the area with ringworm, wash your hands before touching another area of your body. Ring worm thrives in warm, moist areas, so you want keep the area clean and dry. Avoid wearing clothes, socks, and shoes that make you sweat. Shower after working out and avoid sharing towels and other personal items. To avoid reinfecting yourself with infected items, you should wash clothes, towels, and bedding that you use while you have ringworm. Be sure to wash everything in hot, soapy water. If you suspect your pet has ringworm, take the animal to your vet as some types of ring worms grow on pets. Apply topical antifungal cream (preferrably azoles group like miconazole or clotrimazole) twice daily for 2-4 weeks and sometimes systemic antifungal is used in resistant cases.

This is a case of Alopecia areata, an autoimmune non-infectious disease that causes hair loss. Hair may regrow on its own in about a year, and some people never have another episode of hair loss. Sometimes, hair needs help to regrow. Without treatment, hair loss may remain the same or worsen. With treatment, it’s possible to see some regrowth in 6 weeks. However, it takes months for full regrowth. A common treatment plan involves applying a corticosteroid to regrow your hair and later minoxidil (Rogaine®) to keep the hair that’s regrown. Use a soft-bristled brush and wide-tooth comb to gently style your hair. These styling tools are less likely to pull on your hair. Avoid hair and skin care products with harsh chemicals on your scalp. Let your hair dry naturally instead of using a blow dryer or other dryers that use heat. Wear loose hairstyles. Tight hairstyles like ponytails and cornrows can pull on your scalp, causing further hair loss. Referral to a dermatologist is recommended for prescription-strength corticosteroids, injection of steroids, contact immunotherapy, and systemic treatments like biologic treatment.

Most propably it is a case of acne vulgaris. Acne is largely a hormonal condition that’s driven by androgen hormones (testosterone). This typically becomes active during teenage and young adult years. Mild acne can be treated with over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as gels, soaps, pads, creams, and lotions, that are applied to the skin. Creams and lotions are best for sensitive skin. Alcohol-based gels dry the skin and are better for oily skin. It is advisable to start with the lowest strengths, as some preparations can cause skin irritation, redness, or burning on first use. Topical acne medications include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.

It is a case of rosacea, a chronic inflammatory skin condition predominantly affecting the central face and most often starts between the age of 30–60 years. Rosacea is common and is characterised by persistent facial redness. It typically has a relapsing and remitting course, with symptoms controlled by lifestyle measures, general skin care, medications, and procedural interventions. Rosacea has been associated with depression, hypertension, cardiovascular diseases, anxiety disorder, dyslipidemia, diabetes mellitus, migraines, and rheumatoid arthritis. Identify the trigger (Common triggers include spicy food, hot/cold temperatures (hot baths), exercise, sun exposure, cosmetic products, medications (those that cause vasodilation), alcohol, fruits and vegetables, dairy, marinated meat products) and avoid it. Moisturize frequently. Use gentle over-the-counter cleansers. Use mild, synthetic detergent-based cleansers rather than traditional soaps due to risk of irritation. Use physical sunscreens ( zinc oxide/titanium oxide) with SPF ≥ 30, provides broad-spectrum UV radiation and visible light protection and may be better tolerated than chemical sunscreens. Avoid exfoliants. Avoid alcohol-based topical products. Avoid use of topical steroids as they may aggravate the condition. Cosmetics with a green tint are useful to minimize the appearance of redness. Use topical brimonidine, topical oxymetazoline, Intense pulsed light therapy, Vascular laser, Topical azelaic acid (for mild/moderate only), Topical ivermectin, Topical metronidazole (for mild/moderate only), Topical erythromycin, Oral tetracyclines (oxytetracycline, lymecycline, doxycycline), Oral macrolides (erythromycin, azithromycin), Oral metronidazole, Oral isotretinoin often at low dose (for refractory disease only). Although rosacea is not a life-threatening condition, it is a chronic disease that requires long-term management of relapsing and remitting symptoms.

It is a case of nevus sebaceous, a type of epidermal naevus and classified as a benign hair follicle tumour. Most sebaceous nevi remain unchanged throughout life and do not cause any problems. However, in 10–20% of cases, another secondary tumour may grow within the lesion which is our case. These secondary tumors may be benign like trichoblastoma or malignant like basal cell carcinoma. Referral to a dermatologist is recommended for skin biopsy or excision.

This is a case of superficial telangiectasias, small blood vessels that sit near the skin’s surface and widen and create visible patterns of lines. People often refer to them as spider veins. They can occur anywhere on the body or face. For most people, telangiectasias neither cause any damage to overall health nor require treatment. However, they can sometimes indicate a more severe medical condition and may warrant closer inspection. There is no cure for telangiectasia, but it is treatable. Laser therapy is minimally invasive and is typically the most straightforward treatment for telangiectasia and broken capillaries. Laser ablation can seal the widened blood vessels. This procedure does not cause much pain, and the recovery time is short. Sclerotherapy is also an effective option where a solution is injected into the veins causing inflammation and hence shrinkage of the veins.

Most propably this is one of the photodermatoses, as it is mainly confined to sun exposed areas (V sign). It is usually caused by prolonged sun exposure. Photosensitivity is classified into the following groups:
Primary photodermatoses where exposure to the sun produces a clearly defined disease entity, exogenous photodermatoses in which phototoxic or photoallergic reaction is caused by an external photosensitiser like drugs and photocontact dermatitis, and Photoexacerbated dermatoses that include autoimmune diseases like lupus erythematosus and dermatomyositis. Photosensitivity is caused by an abnormal reaction to some component of the electromagnetic spectrum of sunlight. Management of photosensitivity involves sun protection and treatment of the underlying disorder. Select a sunscreen with a very high Sun Protection Factor (SPF 50+), which is a water-resistant and broad-spectrum product. Sunscreens containing reflectants such as zinc may be more effective than pure chemical sunscreens, as they filter out more UVA. Take vitamin D supplements and Confine summer excursions out of doors to early in the morning or late in the evening. Cover up, wearing shirts with high collar and long sleeves, trousers or a long skirt, socks and shoes, a wide-brimmed hat, and if possible gloves. Wear opaque sun-protective clothing. Dark coloured and densely woven fabric is the most effective. Some clothes are now labelled with UPF, the sun protection factor for fabrics. Choose those with a UPF of 40+. Protect their skin indoors and when in a vehicle. Apply UVR-absorbing film to windows at home or in the car. Wear a clear plastic mask to protect the face. Oral antioxidants may be helpful.

It is a case of lymphatic malformation, a type of vascular naevus or birthmark due to malformed and dilated lymphatic vessels. Lymphangioma circumscriptum is benign (non-cancerous) and usually requires no treatment. Antibiotics may be given if secondary infection occurs (rare). If necessary it may be removed surgically, by dermabrasion or by laser. They have a tendency to recur after treatment.

Comedones are pores or hair follicles that have gotten blocked with bacteria, oil, and dead skin cells to form a bump on your skin. Squeezing blackheads and whiteheads can remove them, but can also damage the skin. Doing so increases the risk of causing or transmitting infection and scarring, as well as potentially pushing any infection deeper into the skin. Comedo extractors are used with careful hygiene in beauty salons and by dermatologists, usually after using steam or warm water. Macrocomedones (1 mm or larger) can be removed by a dermatologist using surgical instruments or cauterized with a device that uses light. Some research suggests that the common acne medications like topical retinoids and azelaic acid are beneficial and do not cause increased pigmentation of the skin. If using a topical retinoid, sunscreen is recommended.

It doesn't seem like a wart rather it seems like a healing wound. Try to apply moisturizer containing panthenol, petrolatum, shea butter, or beeswax to speed up the healing process. If it is still persistent you can consult your dermatologist to rule out the presence of a wart using dermoscopic examination.

Failure to identify and repair an acute nail bed defect in a timely fashion may result in less than satisfactory nail plate regeneration. Minor nail bed injuries, including subungual hematomas, often heal on their own, especially when no other injuries are present. People with nail bed injuries may need a course of antibiotics to prevent infection. No treatment is required for subungual haemorrhage in the majority of cases. Occasionally the nail plate is best removed, and the nail bed is surgically repaired. A surgical opinion should be sought if there is an underlying fracture or for biopsy if melanoma cannot be excluded.

Rest and pain relief, protective ointment applied to the rash, such as petroleum jelly, and oral antibiotics for secondary infection are recommnded. Antiviral treatment can reduce pain and the duration of symptoms if started within one to three days after the onset of herpes zoster. Aciclovir 800 mg 5 times daily for seven days is most often prescribed.

HPV is given or received through skin contact or contamination. If you pick at your wart or touch it, you may create another wart on a different part of your skin. People with subungual warts will often start to pick or bite at their nails to relieve pain and try to get at the wart. Unfortunately, this is usually how subungual warts spread and stay in your body for so long. Treatment options include salicylic acid application directly on your wart, cryotherapy, Immunotherapy, laser treatment, or topical cantharidin. It is recommended to consult your dermatologist.
